title: What mindsets and behaviours keep people poor? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve written about wealth, on Quora, for two years. Had millions of views, thousands of upvotes and comments. Most are appreciative. A few trolls, who have no life. Occasional complainers. Who comment at great length, in minute detail. They explain how I don’t understand. And why, what I wrote won’t work. I reply and try to clarify, if I feel they’re asking an honest question. I used to answer the other complainers also. Not anymore. They have endless rebuttals and I have far more fun things to do. In my profession, I counsel people everyday about how to succeed financially. Thankfully most listen and respond positively. Which works for them. And otherwise I’d need to find a job at Walmart. A few explain to me all the reasons they can’t do what I advise. Occasionally, one just never comes back. I guess, I didn’t open my box of magic tricks and show them how they could keep doing what they’re doing. Which isn’t working, except now, they’ll be rich. Yet, I went through a near bankruptcy in a business I owned. Learned to invest. Most times successfully. Sometimes by taking very costly seminars also known as dumb ass mistakes. Spent personally rewarding and financially retarded years pastoring a church. Then started my current business. During the first six months it looked like it was going to be a very exciting and costly experiment. Through it all I learned about building wealth. Built it myself. And helped many others navigate successfully the piranha infested waters. So when someone says, “You just don’t understand.” I usually respond, “You’re right.” And I think, “No I don’t understand making excuses. And, ‘May the Force be with you.’” We can choose to play the victim or the victor. Only one leads to wealth.

I’m going to assume that you’re referring to poor people in the developed world.  As I’ve written about elsewhere in this forum my wife & I come from humble beginnings and we’ve known a fair number of “poor” people.  A small number are family, mostly related by marriage.  (As much as possible we keep them at “arm’s length.”)   The poor tend to “live in the moment” and not think long-term.  I’m reminded of the saying, “The rich plan for the next three generations and the poor plan for Saturday night.”   From their point-of-view nothing that goes wrong in their lives is ever their fault; they were in the grip of forces or circumstances, to include events that happened long before they were born, beyond their control.   They tend to act on impulse. They tend to be poor at weighing risk versus consequences and doing “cost/benefit analysis.”  Arguably anyone who smokes is deficient in those two skills. They tend to not understand the Principle of Causality; cause-and-effect relationships. Cause:  Don’t apply yourself in school; have children out-of-wedlock; engage in substance-abuse; avoid work.  Effect: Remain poor. Cause: Spend your money on cigarettes, drugs, alcohol, fighting DUI/DWIs, lottery-tickets, “bling,” the latest smart-phone and flat-screen TV (even though there was nothing wrong with the phone & TV that you already had).  Effect: Don’t save any money; remain poor.Life at the Bottom
